distinguishing_features: Distinct 'spectacle' or 'binocle' pattern on the dorsal side of the hood
Dark body coloration with lighter ventral scales/bands

similar_candidates.why_not: Typically exhibits a single ocellus (monocle) pattern on the hood, not the double spectacle mark seen here.
Generally much larger, has a different head and scale morphology, and typically lacks the distinct spectacle pattern on the hood.

conservation.protected_status: Protected under Schedule II of the Wildlife Protection Act, 1972 (India)

danger_profile.threat_to_humans: Highly dangerous; a bite can be fatal without immediate medical intervention.
danger_profile.evidence: Species is known to be highly venomous; visible hood display indicates defensive posture. Context states 'snake in house'.

habitat_context.environment: Terrestrial, likely disturbed or semi-urban area (dirt ground with sparse vegetation).
habitat_context.human_impact: Direct human-wildlife interaction due to the snake being found 'in house', indicating habitat encroachment or displacement.

risk_assessment.ai-report: A highly venomous Spectacled Cobra found inside a house poses an immediate and severe threat to human safety. This incident highlights critical human-wildlife conflict driven by habitat loss.
